info.title: Configuring networks using NetworkManager
info.meta: About NetworkManager and how to use it to manage your network connections
NetworkManager and nmcli usage to configure the network.

listitem.para: The article covers the basics of NetworkManager and the usage of the CLI tool to configure the network.
You are using NetworkManager, and you want to configure your network.
It takes approx. 15 minutes to go through this article.
You will have a better understanding of how NetworkManager works and how network connections can be configured.

abstract.para: NetworkManager is a program that manages the primary network connection and other connection interfaces. NetworkManager has been designed to be fully automatic by default. NetworkManager is handled by systemd and is shipped with all necessary service unit files.

section.para: NetworkManager stores all network configurations as a connection, which is a collection of data that describes how to create or connect to a network. These connections are stored as files in the /etc/NetworkManager/system-connections/ directory.

A connection is active when a particular device uses the connection. The device may have more than one connection configured, but only one can be active at a given time. The other connections can be used to fast switch from one connection to another. For example, if the active connection is not available, NetworkManager tries to connect the device to another configured connection.
To manage connections, use the nmcli command, described in the .
The main configuration file for the NetworkManager is /etc/NetworkManager/NetworkManager.conf. This file can be used to configure the behavior of NetworkManager.

The file consists of sections of key-value pairs. Each key-value pair must belong to a section. A section starts with a name enclosed in []. Lines beginning with a # are considered comments. The minimal configuration needs to include the [main] section with the plugins value:
The keyfile plug-in supports all the connection types and capabilities of NetworkManager.
The default configuration file contains the connectivity section that specifies the URI to check the network connection.
On SUSE Linux Micro, you can also use other sections. For details, refer to networkmanager.conf(5) or Gnome's developer guide.
As NetworkManager is a systemd service, you can use common systemd commands to start, stop, or restart NetworkManager.

section.title: The device subcommand
section.para: The device subcommand enables you to show and manage network interfaces. The nmcli device command recognizes the following commands:

listitem.para: to print the status of all devices.
shows detailed information about a device. If no device is specified, all devices are displayed.
to connect a device. NetworkManager tries to find a suitable connection that will be activated. If there is no compatible connection, a new profile is created.
performs temporary changes to the configuration that is active on the particular device. The changes are not stored in the connection profile.
listitem.screen: # nmcli device modify DEVICE_NAME [+|-] SETTING.PROPERTY VALUE
listitem.para: For possible SETTING.PROPERTY values, refer to nm-settings-nmcli(5).
The example below starts the IPv4 shared connection sharing on the device con1.
listitem.screen: # nmcli dev modify con1 ipv4.method shared

listitem.para: disconnects a device and prevents the device from automatically activating further connections without manual intervention.
to delete the interface from the system. You can use the command to delete only software devices like bonds and bridges. You cannot delete hardware devices with this command.
lists all available access points.
connects to a Wi-Fi network specified by its SSID or BSSID. The command takes the following options:
password - password for secured networks
ifname - interface used for activation
name - you can give the connection a name

listitem.screen: # nmcli device wifi connect SSID [password PASSWORD_VALUE] [ifname INTERFACE_NAME]
listitem.para: To connect to a Wi-Fi GUESTWiFi with a password pass$word2#@@, run:
listitem.screen: # nmcli device wifi connect GUESTWiFi password pass$word2#@@

section.title: The general subcommand
section.para: You can use this command to view NetworkManager status and permissions, and change the host name and logging level. The nmcli general recognizes the following commands:

listitem.para: displays the overall status of NetworkManager. Whenever you do not specify a command to the nmcli general command, status is used by default.
if you do not provide a new host name as an argument, the current host name is displayed. If you specify a new host name, the value is used to set a new host name.
For example, to set MyHostname, run:
shows your permission for NetworkManager operations like enabling or disabling networking, modifying connections, etc.
shows and changes NetworkManager logging levels and domains. Without any arguments, the command displays current logging levels and domains.
listitem.screen: # nmcli general logging [level LEVEL domains DOMAIN]
listitem.para: LEVEL is any of the values: OFF, ERR, WARN, INFO, DEBUG, or TRACE.

DOMAIN is a list of values that can be as follows: PLATFORM, RFKILL, ETHER, WIFI, BT, MB, DHCP4, DHCP6, PPP, WIFI_SCAN, IP4, IP6, AUTOIP4, DNS, VPN, SHARING, SUPPLICANT, AGENTS, SETTINGS, SUSPEND, CORE, DEVICE, OLPC, WIMAX, INFINIBAND, FIREWALL, ADSL, BOND, VLAN, BRIDGE, DBUS_PROPS, TEAM, CONCHECK, DCB, DISPATCH, AUDIT, SYSTEMD, VPN_PLUGIN, PROXY.

section.title: The networking subcommand
section.para: The subcommand enables you to query the status of the network. Also, by using this command, you can enable or disable networking. The nmcli networking command takes the following commands:

listitem.para: enables or disables networking. The off command deactivates all interfaces managed by NetworkManager.
displays the network connectivity state. If check is used, NetworkManager performs a new check of the state. Otherwise, the last detected state is displayed.
Possible states are the following:
none - the host is not connected to any network.
portal - the host is behind a captive portal and cannot reach the full Internet.
limited - the host is connected to a network, but it has no access to the Internet.
full - the host is connected to a network and has full access to the Internet.
unknown - NetworkManager could not determine the network state.
